thread.title: Kenya: Cord Leaders to Tour Bungoma Over Sugar Deal
thread.title_full: Kenya: Cord Leaders to Tour Bungoma Over Sugar Deal

title: Kenya: Cord Leaders to Tour Bungoma Over Sugar Deal
text:
Kenya: American Singer Blasts Rapper Octopizzo 
The Odm director of communications said the rallies will take place at Bungoma Bus Park, Kanduyi Shopping Centre and Bukembe 
Etale said the Uganda - Kenya sugar deal signed by President Uhuru Kenyatta is unacceptable noting that "it is with this reason that the Cord leadership have lined up a series of meetings in Bungoma during the tour". 
"The consequences of the deal are grave to the country's sugar cane farmer and the local industry which will effectively collapse and millions of Kenyans lose their livelihoods," he said. 
He noted that 50 members of parliament who are both in the senate and the National Assembly have confirmed their presence during the tour. 
Etale said the visit to Kakamega County has been rescheduled and will now be held in two weeks time. 
This comes after ODM asked the public to boycott Brookside Dairy milk products in protest to the Kenya-Uganda sugar deal. 
This follows a claim by Cord co-principal Moses Wetang'ula that Uhuru "mortgaged" 10 million poor Kenyans in the sugar belt to secure a market for Brookside milk. 
"We call on our people to rethink their relationship with the companies in whose name our sugar sector is being killed," said ODM deputy organising secretary Florence Mutua. 
"Boycott the milk that is being exported to Uganda. Let Ugandans buy it." 
Raila who has been accused of the woes surrounding Mumias threatened to sue Majority leader Aden Duale for alleging he owes the company over Sh40 million. 
Raila said Duale should make a settlement within seven days for implying he was responsible for the collapse of the company and that "he lacks integrity as a politician and is undeserving of his role as a leader". 
He said Duale portrayed him as a "debt defaulter who unlawfully withheld from the people of Western province money which is rightfully due". 
"The words are also understood to mean that our client pursues a deliberate political strategy to impoverish the people of Kenya," Raila's lawyer Paul Mwangi said in a letter. 
Mwangi said Duale's "derogating language was malicious, insulting and meant to accentuate the harm and injury inflicted to Raila". 
This comes after Duale poked Raila over the Kenya - Uganda sugar deal, saying "after being cagey and evasive, Raila has confessed that he owes the poor sugar cane farmers what he casually and callously terms a commercial loan" Kenya 
American singer August Alsina has denied ever collaborating on a song with Kenyan rapper Octopizzo. see more » Copyright © 2015 The Star. All rights reserved.
